title: arange(0.1, 0.5, 0.05) returns wrong results
body_html:
import torch, numpy as np

torch.arange(0.1, 0.50, 0.05)
# 0.1000
# 0.1500
# 0.2000
# 0.2500
# 0.3000
# 0.3500
# 0.4000
#[torch.FloatTensor of size 7]


np.arange(0.1, 0.50, 0.05, dtype = np.float32)
#array([0.1       , 0.15      , 0.20000002, 0.25      , 0.3       ,
#       0.35000002, 0.4       , 0.45000002], dtype=float32)

0.45 is missing from PyTorch output, which seems strange, 0.45 is clearly less than 0.50, even considering floating point errror.

on 0.4.0a0+1fdb392

I guess the cause is that arange computes number of elements by floor((end - start) / step) and float error impacts this calculation, but the departure from NumPy behavior in simple cases like this (not even #4877) may be confusing.

body:
```python
import torch, numpy as np

torch.arange(0.1, 0.50, 0.05)
# 0.1000
# 0.1500
# 0.2000
# 0.2500
# 0.3000
# 0.3500
# 0.4000
#[torch.FloatTensor of size 7]


np.arange(0.1, 0.50, 0.05, dtype = np.float32)
#array([0.1       , 0.15      , 0.20000002, 0.25      , 0.3       ,
#       0.35000002, 0.4       , 0.45000002], dtype=float32)
```

0.45 is missing from PyTorch output, which seems strange, 0.45 is clearly less than 0.50, even considering floating point errror.

on `0.4.0a0+1fdb392`

I guess the cause is that `arange` computes number of elements by `floor((end - start) / step)` and float error impacts this calculation, but the departure from NumPy behavior in simple cases like this (not even https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/4877) may be confusing.
